Info.Label: Expermental Feature
Info.Description: Generates a smoothness map from the input image. A smoothness map is commonly used in 3D graphics to determine the shininess or glossiness of a surface. Brighter values indicate smoother, shinier areas, while darker values represent rougher, more diffuse regions.

Properties.Name: Invert
Properties.Summary: Inverts the bright and dark values in the smoothness map when toggled on, making bright areas dark and vice versa.

Properties.Name: Base Smoothness
Properties.Summary: Sets the overall smoothness level for the image. Higher values create a smoother, shinier surface, while lower values result in a rougher, more diffuse appearance.

Properties.Name: Smoothness Multiplier
Properties.Summary: Adjusts the range of smoothness values. Higher values increase the contrast between smooth and rough areas, while lower values reduce this contrast.

Properties.Name: High-Pass Radius
Properties.Summary: Determines the size of details targeted by the high-pass filter. A higher radius affects larger details, while a lower radius targets smaller details.

Properties.Name: High-Pass Strength
Properties.Summary: Controls the intensity of the high-pass filter effect. Higher values make details more prominent, while lower values lessen the emphasis.

Properties.Name: Bias
Properties.Summary: Shifts the overall brightness of the smoothness map. Increasing the bias results in a brighter, shinier appearance, while decreasing it makes the surface more diffuse.

Properties.Name: Contrast
Properties.Summary: Enhances or reduces the differences between bright and dark areas in the smoothness map. Higher values create more variation in shininess, while lower values produce a more uniform appearance.

Info.Label: Recommendation:
Info.Text: For optimal results, it is recommended to first generate a height map from the base image and then use this height map as the source to generate the smoothness map.
